messages: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (11:48): Jeezus I am muting the *crap* out of the warning thread.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:51): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: well, it seems to me that Hixie should have seen this coming and it was blatantly unproductive to put a warning like that in the draft

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (11:51): Man, I don't even care about that.  I care about the fact that we have significant chatter going on between *adults* on whether it's appropriate to mark up the warning with an <em> or not.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:52): maybe Hixie was placing bets on how long it would take until the shit hit the fan
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (11:53): If so, I hope he won, because the rest of us lose.  >_<
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:53): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: I haven't read far enough to reach an <em> debate
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (11:53): Dammit why doesn't muting work.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:54): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: you need (CA-3) Support separate volume control of the different audio tracks.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:59): I was quite surprised that Sicking posted that about <em>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:00): Oh and I agree with b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 about the media thing fwiw
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:00): It doesn't seem to have changed substantially since it was last discussed here and we were told it was about to change substantially
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (12:00): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: i know, it's really a too silly discussion to get involved with
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (12:01): i'm just surprised when accessibility experts advocate misusing semantic elements in the name of accessibility
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (12:01): it's shocking that AT doesn't support <em>
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (12:01): no wonder the state of accessibility is so poor if we have to keep working around such AT vendors
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:11): the edit wars continued through the night
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:11): oh god
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:12): Hmm, HTML5 requires object@data served as image/* gets sniffed. Opera doesn't.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:13): is unaware of anything needing it to be sniffed‚Ä¶
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:22): sniffed for what?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:26): e.g. that image/png can carry image/gif
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:26): I suspect
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:26): Yeah
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:26): opera doesn't do that?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:26): Oh, wait, I'm being dumb
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:27): is getting stuff mixed up in his mind
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:28): What we don't sniff is object served as text/plain
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:28): The spec seems to fail to set the resource type in that case
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:29): does the spec match mozilla?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:29): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-object-element 4.7.4.4
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:29): It defines resource type when binary is false, but not when it is true
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:29): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I think the spec doesn't say.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:29): And then in 4.8 you then have an undefined variable.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:30): Oh, it's set initially to unknown
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:30): decides to not try to follow
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:31): Look at the spec.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:31): You have a PNG served as text/plain.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:31): What happens?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:40): uh, yeah, it gets sniffed as application/octet-stream by MIMESNIFF and thus sets binary to true, but doesn't say what happens next
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:41): or step 8 goes to the Otherwise case
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:41): falls into the otherwise case, no?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:41): Which matches nothing.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:42): Yeah, was going to once someone checked I wasn't being silly. :)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:43): wait, doesn't it match "If the resource type is an XML MIME type, or if the resource type does not start with "image/"" ?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:45): I wasn't sure.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:45): application/octet-stream is a type that does not start with "image/"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:46): How is application/octet-stream the value of resource-type?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:47): Like, where does "resource type" get set apart from to unknown?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:48): "resource type" seems to be set by type=""
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:49): and the file extension
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:50): If you have <object data="data:text/plain,%89PNG‚Ä¶"></object>
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:50): so in our case it seems to be "unknown"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:50): Indeed.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:51): though "unknown" also doesn't start with "image/" :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:51): Indeed :)
